results.headline: The Aftershocks of an Adoption Long Ago, Felt by Everyone Involved
results.summary_short: “I’m Glad My Mother Is Alive,” directed by the father-son team of Claude and Nathan Miller, focuses on the psychological profile of a boy who finds the woman who gave him up for adoption.

results.headline: Robert Duvall Is Back in the Saddle, Playing a Mentor to a Young Golfer
results.summary_short: In “Seven Days in Utopia,” an ambitious young professional golfer runs his car onto the property of a weather-beaten rancher.

results.headline: In the Green Zone, Armed With a Bottle of Hot Sauce
results.summary_short: Beto Goméz’s “Saving Private Pérez” takes a comedic approach to its underlying theme: what constitutes a hero in today’s Mexico.

results.headline: A Sly Corporate Dance That Turns Into a Duel
results.summary_short: Alain Corneau’s “Love Crime” works as a devilish satire on power and eros in the executive suite.

results.headline: A Haunting in the E.R.
results.summary_short: Natalie Zea portrays a nurse who suddenly finds herself sharing the memories of a murdered woman in Richard Gabai’s new psychological-supernatural thriller, “InSight.”

results.headline: Room for a Toddler Act in This Gloomy Circus Life
results.summary_short: In “Little Girl (La Pivellina)” an aging circus performer and her husband take in a little girl who is left near their trailer on the outskirts of Rome.

results.headline: He’s Always Around, Showing Off His Muscles
results.summary_short: In “Bodyguard” the Bollywood star Salman Khan flexes frequently, and the audience goes wild.

results.headline: After 9/11, Grappling With Grief and Rage
results.summary_short: The film diligently tracks the lives of five people who were profoundly affected by the attacks on the World Trade Center.

results.headline: ‘Je T’Aime,’ He Sang, to His Women and Himself
results.summary_short: Joann Sfar’s “Gainsbourg: A Heroic Life” is an affectionate tribute to Serge Gainsbourg, the bad boy of French pop music in the ‘60s and ‘70s.

results.headline: Heroic Past Erodes in Present
results.summary_short: Helen Mirren, Tom Wilkinson and Ciaran Hinds play three aging Mossad operatives revisiting their actions during the cold war in John Madden’s latest film, “The Debt.”

results.headline: Navigating Between Faith and Skepticism
results.summary_short: Vera Farmiga stars in this film, her directorial debut, a drama that weighs the merits of faith against a secular sensibility.

results.headline: A Meek Rose Amid the Mods and Rockers in an English Resort Town
results.summary_short: The director Rowan Joffe has turned “Brighton Rock,” Graham Greene’s novel rooted in Brighton’s seedy underworld, into a full-scale film noir.

results.headline: She Walks in Beauty, and Brings Along a Bazooka
results.summary_short: In “Colombiana,” directed by Olivier Megaton, Zoe Saldana takes her place among big-screen heroines who play very rough.

results.headline: For One Family in Serenity, Ohio, It Seems Life Is Anything but Serene
results.summary_short: “The Family Tree,” a satirical farce about a dysfunctional family, set to a naggingly perky sitcom-style soundtrack.

results.headline: They Have Coveted Christmas Meat, Now How Do They Eat It in Peace?
results.summary_short: “Tales,” overseen by Cristian Mungiu, is a hearty satirical guffaw of gallows humor that illustrates how laughter helped buoy the spirits of an oppressed citizenry.

results.headline: A Feminist Spin on the Sexploitation Genre

results.summary_short: A goofy man-child of a brother ends up exposing the hypocrisy and unhappiness of everyone around him.
